Many sports apparel brands have committed to reducing or eliminating the use of harmful chemicals in their products, both to protect the environment and maintain safe and healthy working conditions for factory workers. Here are a few examples of what some brands are doing:

1. Nike: Nike has a Restricted Substances List (RSL) that sets limits on the use of harmful chemicals in its products, and all Nike suppliers are required to comply with this list. The company also uses safer chemistry and sustainable materials whenever possible to reduce the use of harmful chemicals in its products.

2. Adidas: Adidas has committed to eliminating the use of hazardous chemicals in its products and supply chain by 2020. The company uses a Chemical Management System to assess the safety of chemicals used in its products, and requires its suppliers to comply with strict chemical restrictions.

3. Patagonia: Patagonia is known for its sustainability practices, and has established a set of environmental standards for its products, including a list of banned chemicals that are known to be hazardous to human health and the environment. Patagonia also uses organic and recycled materials in its products to reduce its environmental impact.

4. Under Armour: Under Armour has implemented a Restricted Substances List (RSL) that sets limits on the use of harmful chemicals in its products, and works with suppliers to ensure compliance with this list. The company also uses sustainable materials in its products, including recycled polyester.

Overall, while there is always room for improvement, many sports apparel brands are taking steps to reduce the use of harmful chemicals in their products and supply chains, while maintaining quality and performance standards.
